issues.text: Whether on a proper construction of the relevant clauses of the appellant companys memorandum of association and articles of association and on a consideration of the circumstances in which the shares of the Sarswati Sugar Syndicate were purchased and sold, it could be held that the purchase and sale of such shares was a part of Appellant companys business deal ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a proper construction of the relevant clauses of the appellant companys memorandum of association and articles of association and on a consideration of the circumstances in which the shares of the Sarswati Sugar Syndicate were purchased and sold, it could be held that the purchase and sale of such shares was a part of Appellant companys business deal ?

issues.text: Whether in the circumstances of the case, the excess of Rs. 20,000 realised in the assessment year 1942-43 and Rs. 2,26,700 in the year 1944-45 was a revenue receipt chargeable to tax under section 3 of the Income-tax Act and was not a mere appreciation of capital ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the circumstances of the case, the excess of Rs. 20,000 realised in the assessment year 1942-43 and Rs. 2,26,700 in the year 1944-45 was a revenue receipt chargeable to tax under section 3 of the Income-tax Act and was not a mere appreciation of capital ? The questions arose in the following circumstances The assessee, a public limited company, which is the appellant before us, was formed in 1917 with the following objects To undertake and carry on the general business and trade of commission agents, insurance agents, commercial agents, export and import agents, clearing and forwarding or house or land agents, bankers and merchants of every description or any other work calculated directly or indirectly to benefit the company,

issues.text: whether it is a receipt from business and not a mere appreciation in capital

anchor.surface_text: non-recurring nature and this fact is noticed by the High Court in their judgment. The only question for consideration therefore is whether it is a receipt from business and not a mere appreciation in capital. An argument was put forward at one stage on behalf of the revenue that the assessee company, by virtue of its memorandum of association, was allowed to deal in money, shares, bills, hundis and other securities and that the shares which were purchased and sold fell within the category of securities. The High Court negatived this contention and Mr. Joshi on behalf of the respondent has also conceded this point.

issues.text: Whether the transaction was an adventure in the nature of trade or an investment resulting in capital appreciation

anchor.surface_text: the intention and purpose of the adventure was to obtain the managing agency of the sugar mill and the directorship in the sugar company and this fell within the object c to undertake the management of commercial undertaken and therefore the true nature of the transaction was an ordinary business operation well within its powers and not one of investment. If the acquisition by the assessee company of the managing agency of a commercial undertaking were outside the objects clause of the memorandum of association then such acquisition would have been wholly ultra vires.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court negatived the contention; respondent conceded the point

arguments.claim: Intention and purpose of the transaction was to obtain managing agency and directorship, which falls within object clause to undertake management of commercial undertakings, hence ordinary business operation and not investment

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held., however, that the intention and purpose of the adventure was to obtain the managing agency of the sugar mill and the directorship in the sugar company and this fell within the object c to undertake the management of commercial undertaken and therefore the true nature of the transaction was an ordinary business operation well within its powers and not one of investment.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: managing agency of the third mill which numberdoubt would have been an asset of an enduring nature

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court erred; no intention to resell shares from inception, isolated transaction, capital nature

arguments.claim: Whether transaction is within company's powers has no bearing on whether profits are capital accretion or revenue income

anchor.surface_text: The circumstance whether a transaction is or is not within its powers has no bearing on the nature of the transaction, or on the question whether the profits arising therefrom are capital accretion or revenue income.

arguments.claim: Memorandum did not authorise dealing in shares as dealers; isolated transaction only, no other share dealings

anchor.surface_text: The exact nature of the business which the assessee company was doing is admittedly not clear from the record but it is not denied that the memorandum of association of the assessee company did not authorise it to purchase and or sell shares as dealers nor is it denied that beyond this isolated transaction of purchase and sale the assessee company did not deal in shares.

arguments.claim: Object in buying shares was to obtain managing agency; no intention from inception to resell or deal in shares

anchor.surface_text: It seems that the object of the assessee company in buying shares was purely to obtain the managing agency of the third mill which no doubt would have been an asset of an enduring nature and would have brought them profits but there was from the inception no intention whatever on the part of the assessee company to re-sell the shares either at a profit or otherwise deal in them.

arguments.claim: Taking up shares was essential part of arrangement for managing agency, hence capital investment and profits accretions to capital

anchor.surface_text: After conceding that the taking up of the shares of Rs. 3,00,000 by the assessee company in the sugar company was an essential part of the arrangement arrived at, the only reasonable conclusion to which the High Court should have come was that the investment of the money in the purchase of shares was of a capital nature and the profits arising out of the sale of the shares in the circumstances of this case were accretions to capital and were not liable to tax.

arguments.claim: Out of Rs. 3,00,000 invested, only Rs. 1,00,000 for managing agency and Rs. 2,00,000 for making profit

anchor.surface_text: but it was contended that out of Rs. 3,00,000 to be invested only Rs. 1,00,000 was invested for acquiring the managing agency and the remaining Rs. 2,00,000 was for the purpose of making a profit.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Lala Kishan Prasad Co. will be appointed managing agents on the same terms as given to the other two ma

arguments.court_reasoning: Not a correct interpretation of the terms of the agreement; letters show otherwise

arguments.claim: Agreement terms embodied in letters show transaction indivisible, sole object to acquire managing agency as permanent asset

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that this would be a correct interpretation of the terms of the agreement. The letter dated 14th March, 1933, which admittedly embodies the terms of the agreement between Lala Kishan Prasad and the directors of the sugar company clearly says that the assessee company would invest Rs. 5,00,000 of their own. ... These two letters leave no doubt that the transaction was one and indivisible and the sole object of the agreement was to acquire the managing agency as an asset of a permanent character in order to have a hold on the directors.

arguments.claim: Purchase of shares was investment not adventure; sums not income from business, not liable to tax

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly reverse the decision of the High Court and hold that the purchase of shares to the tune of Rs. 3,00,000 was an investment and not an adventure and the two sums which were taxed were not in the nature of income from business and were therefore not liable to tax.

holdings.text: The purchase of shares to the tune of Rs. 3,00,000 was an investment and not an adventure and the two sums which were taxed were not in the nature of income from business and were therefore not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly reverse the decision of the High Court and hold that the purchase of shares to the tune of Rs. 3,00,000 was an investment and not an adventure and the two sums which were taxed were not in the nature of income from business and were therefore not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that this would be a correct interpretation of the terms of the agreement. The letter dated 14th March, 1933, which admittedly embodies the terms of the agreement between Lala Kishan Prasad and the directors of the sugar company clearly says that the assessee company would invest Rs. 5,00,000 of their own. ...
